newsitem.title: GERMANY: TARKETT CONFIDENT OF 1997 PROFIT RISE.
newsitem.headline: TARKETT CONFIDENT OF 1997 PROFIT RISE.

text.p: German floor covering manufacturer Tarkett AG on Thursday said it was confident of higher earnings this year after its net profit advanced marginally in the first six months.
In its interim report, Tarkett said its profits should rise in the full year so long as raw materials and product prices remained stable.

The company -- which is currently planning to merge its floor covering business with Sommer Allibert of France to create one of the world leaders in this sector -- reported net profit of 27.9 million marks in the first half of 1997, up from 27.7 million.
Group sales advanced to 753.6 million marks from 666 million marks in the period.
Profits had improved substantially in the second quarter, Tarkett said, when net earnings rose 23.6 percent to 17.3 million marks.

Chief executive Lars Wisen told a news conference he expected a speedy decision from Germany's Federal Cartel Office on Tarkett's merger plans. A ruling could come as early as Thursday or within the next week.
A decision from the U.S. cartel authorities would follow in September, he predicted, so that the merger could go ahead from mid-November.
The deal, announced in May, involves Sommer-Allibert taking a 60 percent stake in Tarkett which in return will pay 705 million marks in cash for Sommer's floor covering business.
The merger will create a company called Tarkett-Sommer AG with annual sales of 2.6 billion marks, 27 plants worldwide and 8,800 employees.
